steps.description:
Localization is interfaced with via the configuration in `package.json`. See [configuration documentation](https://github.com/input-output-hk/gatsby-starter-iohk-default#configuration) for full reference.

Lets start by adding a new language in `availableLanguages` after `en`. First of all stop any processes running the site such as `npm start` etc.

```JavaScript
{
  "key": "fr",
  "label": "FranÃ§ais",
  "flag": "ðŸ‡«ðŸ‡·",
  "locale": "fr_FR"
}
```

Now that we've added a new language we need to create the content in that language. Luckily it's just as easy as running `npm run create-pages -- /`. This will create the additional markdown we require for `fr`. If we tried to run `npm start` prior to creating the markdown for the language we would have got an error letting us know that no content existed for the home page of that language.
We'll also need to create the localized 404 page content. Go ahead and copy this file in the same directory and name it `404-fr.md`.
We'll also need to create the localized 404 page meta data. Go ahead and copy this file in the same directory and name it `404-fr.md`.
We'll also need to create the localized global content. Go ahead and copy this file in the same directory and name it `global-fr.md`.
Now we are ready to run the site. Go ahead and run the `npm start` command and you should see the site available in `FranÃ§ais` via the language selector in the header.

This select language component is the select input that renders in the header of the site. It's a good reference point for how to use consume the language via the [@input-output-hk/front-end-core-components language context](https://github.com/input-output-hk/front-end-core-components/blob/master/docs/components/Language.md).

This is our code which resolves the content from the GraphQL query on content. For a handful of languages this is performant enough, however for dozens of languages a more performant approach may be to resolve the content using the Gatsby node API. This of course depends on the amount of localized content.

The same applies for the global content. If the global content grows to a size where it becomes less performant it may make sense to break the content up into smaller files which are only consumed where they are required.

Congratulations you now have a basic understanding of the localization within the IOHK default Gatsby starter!

* For a more in-depth look at the internals take the tour on the "Core components"
* For design take the tour on "Themes" and "Templates"
* Want to create some pages? Check out the tour "Creating pages" to see how easy it is to create new pages
* For advanced client side routing see the tour on "Client side routing"
